name: Islamic Services Foundation
theoryOfChange: By providing high-quality Islamic education and incubating social-change organizations, ISF empowers the community to thrive across generations.

ui_signals_v1.recommendation_rationale: Context dependent profile. Consider cause fit, risk profile, and evidence maturity before deciding.

components.evidence: Accepts zakat (+2); Muslim-focused organization (+2); Islamic identity (+1)
components.improvement_suggestion: Clarify zakat allocation policy and eligible use categories for donors.
components.name: Muslim Donor Fit

components.improvement_suggestion: Expand services to underserved populations or geographies with limited nonprofit coverage.
components.name: Underserved Space

alignment.rationale: Alignment 21/50: LOW Muslim donor fit, domestic poverty cause area

components.improvement_suggestion: Separate restricted/endowment funds from operating reserves and publish a clear reserve-use policy.
components.name: Financial Health

components.improvement_suggestion: Document a clear theory of change with an explicit causal pathway.
components.name: Theory of Change

risks.description: No outcome measurement or metrics tracking

score_details.score_summary: Islamic Services Foundation shows good impact and moderate alignment, with zakat compliance (minor risk deductions applied).

all_citations.claim: ISF was founded in 1989 and operates schools and endowment programs including full-ride scholarships.
The organization is zakat-eligible and provides multiple donation options.
ISF provides opportunities for community engagement through volunteering.
Financial metrics include a 99.5% program expense ratio, 14.5 months of working capital, and $0.00 fundraising efficiency.
The organization reported total revenue of $14,235,728 and detailed its program expenses and operational structure.

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization demonstrates excellent financial health and efficiency, though its overall score is moderated by a high cost per beneficiary and a specific domestic focus.
areas_for_improvement: Limited external data regarding broad-scale domestic poverty impact metrics
High cost per beneficiary relative to other domestic service models

dimension_explanations.alignment: The foundation shows a moderate alignment with typical donor expectations, offering zakat-eligible giving opportunities and a long track record since 1989 [1][2]. However, the focus on domestic education and specific community services may result in a lower urgency rating compared to international humanitarian crises [1][5].
dimension_explanations.impact: ISF provides direct services through its schools and scholarship programs, maintaining a total revenue of $14,235,728 to support these initiatives [1][5]. While the organization is financially robust with 14.5 months of working capital, the cost per beneficiary is relatively high at approximately $13,220 [4][5].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Islamic Services Foundation is a long-standing non-profit dedicated to empowering the Muslim community through education and sustainable endowment programs.
strengths: Exceptional program expense ratio of 99.5%, indicating nearly all funds go directly to services [4][5]
High fundraising efficiency with $0.00 spent to raise every $1 [4]
Strong liquidity with 14.5 months of working capital available [4]
baseline_narrative.summary: founded in 1989, the Islamic Services Foundation (ISF) operates comprehensive educational institutions and an endowment fund to serve the Muslim community [1][5]. The organization is zakat-eligible and offers various ways for supporters to contribute through donations and volunteerism [2][3].

all_citations.claim: comprehensive educational institutions and sustainable endowment programs
all_citations.quote: Islamic Services Foundation [ISF]. Graduating Class size; Full Ride Scholarships

rich_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization demonstrates excellent financial health and efficiency, though its overall score is moderated by a high cost per beneficiary and a specific domestic focus.

areas_for_improvement.context: The organization currently has a <cite id="4">low percentage of independent board members (15%)</cite>, which may impact objective oversight.
The average cost of <cite id="5">$13,220.62 per beneficiary</cite> is relatively high compared to other global education models, reflecting the intensive nature of private schooling.

bbb_assessment.summary: The organization maintains audited financials but lacks a full BBB Wise Giving Alliance accreditation.

case_against.mitigation_notes: The organization mitigates these costs through significant program service revenue, reducing reliance on pure donations for operational overhead.
risk_factors: <cite id="4">Only 15% of the board is independent</cite>, which is below best-practice standards for non-profit oversight.
The <cite id="5">high cost per beneficiary</cite> may limit the scalability of the impact compared to lower-cost educational interventions.
case_against.summary: The primary concerns involve <cite id="4">governance structure</cite> and the high resource intensity of the school model.

confidence.data_freshness: Financial data current through 2023 tax year
confidence.notes: Financial efficiency is exceptionally high, but governance transparency is a limiting factor.

alignment.explanation: ISF is a strong fit for donors seeking <cite id="2">zakat-eligible educational initiatives</cite> that serve the domestic Muslim community through <cite id="1">Hifz and Islamic schooling</cite>.
alignment.improvement: The organization could improve alignment by <cite id="2">clarifying specific zakat allocation policies</cite> across its various asnaf categories like fuqara and fisabilillah.

credibility.explanation: Donors can find confidence in ISF's <cite id="1">37-year track record</cite> and its consistent <cite id="5">audited financial reporting</cite> through the IRS. However, credibility is tempered by a <cite id="4">lack of independent board leadership</cite>.
credibility.improvement: To strengthen credibility, the charity should increase its <cite id="4">independent board membership</cite> beyond the current 15% and publish a clear conflict-of-interest policy.

impact.explanation: The foundation shows high directness through <cite id="1">direct provision of schooling and scholarships</cite>, supported by a <cite id="4">100.0% program ratio</cite>.
impact.improvement: Impact measurement would benefit from <cite id="1">documenting a clear theory of change</cite> that explicitly links educational inputs to long-term socio-economic outcomes for graduates.

donor_fit_matrix.evidence_rigor: Grade C - Verified outcomes with developing theory of change

grantmaking_profile.grant_strategy: Direct service provision through owned schools and financial aid to students

rich_narrative.headline: The Islamic Services Foundation is a long-standing non-profit dedicated to empowering the Muslim community through education and sustainable endowment programs.

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who value long-term investment in Islamic educational infrastructure and want to support zakat-eligible domestic schooling with high financial efficiency.
donor_motivations: Want to support the preservation of Islamic identity through Hifz and formal education
Value organizations with a multi-decade track record in the US
Prefer charities where 100% of donations are directed to program services
Interested in building sustainable community endowments
giving_considerations: The organization has a very stable financial base with high reserves
Governance is centralized with limited independent board oversight
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors seeking high-volume international relief or those who prioritize organizations with high board independence ratings.

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: Grade C reflects verified output data (graduates, scholarships) but a lack of rigorous longitudinal impact studies.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: ISF creates impact by providing high-quality Islamic and academic education, supported by financial aid and endowments, to produce community leaders.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that the high cost of private education translates into measurable community benefits and student success.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While the organization is growing rapidly, its high reserves suggest it is currently well-capitalized for existing operations.

peer_comparison.differentiator: Distinguished by a <cite id="4">99.5% program expense ratio</cite>, which significantly exceeds the <cite id="4">peer median of 89.6%</cite>.

similar_organizations.differentiator: Smaller scale with similar K-12 focus
similar_organizations.name: Muslim American Youth Foundation

similar_organizations.differentiator: Broader social service focus beyond education
similar_organizations.name: Inner-City Muslim Action Network

strengths.detail: The organization directs a <cite id="4">99.5% program expense ratio</cite> toward its services, ensuring that donor contributions are utilized for direct community impact.
ISF demonstrates high efficiency by spending <cite id="4">$0.00 to raise every $1</cite> in contributions, maximizing the net value of every donation.
With <cite id="4">14.5 months of working capital</cite> held in working capital, the foundation maintains a healthy buffer against economic volatility.

strengths_deep_dive: The Islamic Services Foundation's financial model is characterized by its ability to generate significant program service revenue, which totaled <cite id="5">$10,415,037 in 2023</cite>. This diversified income stream, combined with <cite id="5">$3,565,503 in public contributions</cite>, allows the organization to maintain its <cite id="1">ISF Schools and Endowment funds</cite> with high stability. Their long-term commitment is further evidenced by a <cite id="5">3-year revenue CAGR of 23.2%</cite>, indicating steady growth and expanding community trust since its <cite id="1">founding in 1989</cite>.
rich_narrative.summary: founded in 1989, the Islamic Services Foundation (ISF) has established itself as a cornerstone of the American Muslim community through its focus on <cite id="1">comprehensive educational institutions and sustainable endowment programs</cite>. The organization operates with a significant financial footprint, reporting <cite id="5">$14,235,728 in total revenue</cite> for the 2023 fiscal year. ISF's model is unique in its high degree of financial efficiency, maintaining a <cite id="4">99.5% program expense ratio</cite>, which suggests that nearly all functional expenses are directed toward its core missions of education and community service. Beyond its flagship ISF Schools, the foundation manages a <cite id="1">Qur’an Hifz Program and provides student financial aid</cite> to ensure accessibility. The organization's impact is evidenced by its recent outcomes, including a <cite id="1">graduating class of 72 students</cite> and the provision of <cite id="1">8 full-ride scholarships</cite> to support academic excellence within the community. While primarily focused on domestic education, ISF also facilitates humanitarian efforts through partnerships, such as <cite id="1">providing 196,650 meals via cooperation with ANERA</cite>.
